title: What is the interrelationship between time and the absolute immutability in ancient traditions?
first_phrase: The text discusses the concept of time and the interrelationship between human knowledge and the absolute immutability. The author mentions H. Gomperz's works and the Indian concept of "time subtle" as a middle ground between human experience and absolute immutability. The text emphasizes the importance of constant references to the actions and sufferings of gods in ancient texts. The last part of the text delves into the contrast between the necessity of nature and the concept of free will. The author warns against making the same mistake as the positive scientist and confusing uniformity with necessity in psychological and social laws.

Come le leggi fisiche, cos le leggi psicologico-sociali poggiano sopra un calcolo delle pro babilità, sopra una statistica giustificata nelle sue gene ralizzazioni dalla « legge dei grandi numeri ».
last_phrase: In conclusion, while there may be laws of uniformity that govern both physical and social phenomena, individual variability and spontaneity play a role that cannot be easily accounted for. Therefore, in considering the actions of individuals, it is crucial to acknowledge the unpredictability that may lie within a statistically uniform group. Any predictions made are merely within the realm of probability and not certainty, and the idea of active spontaneity cannot be disregarded.
